reviewText:
Let's get one questions out of the way - is this game pay2win? YES. It is a solid, honest YES.

You have access to virtually all cards, but only in theory. In reality it would take the player months if not years to actually collect enough cards for a competitive decks. Once again we have the Energy-Bar, a fake, useless currency that you get tiny amounts of and the real currency, which of you get even less.

By the numbers:

Gold: 1 Hero costs 70.000 Gold. One Booster with old cards 5.000. One booster with newer cards 20.000. Newest booster are gem only. Each booster contains 6 Common, 3 Uncommon, 1 Rare (and a tiny chance for an Epic or Legendary). A deck consists out of ~40 cards.
Participating in a tournament costs 5 credits" and 10 credits cost 35.000 gold

Now
recommended: how much gold do i get per battle? Well
hoursPlayed: 100. You get about 400 in total after completing one of the nodes on the map and it take 4 battles to complete it. In other words - if you want a new hero
voteText: you will have to finish 700 battles just for that.\n\nThere is also almost no way to earn gems and by that i mean
helpfulPercent:
that you i.e. earn 5 after logging in 50 times and 40 for collecting all cards from one of the collections. One booster costs btw 20 and you can buy 1100 for 100$.

This game is a facebook scam.

reviewText:
Few hours here, but probably a couple thousand via a browser.

Its NOT P2P or P2W.  Energy is almost completely irrelevant, as it regenerates quickly and there are plenty of things to do that don't cost energy.

You can get 7 free packs by doing the advanced tutorials" - through a lightbulb on the bottom left of the campaign screen.  With just these packs
date:
you can easily compete in beginner arena (which is vs AI - there are also two arenas where it is live PvP matchups)

New Devs are GANZ (makers of Webkinz) who seem dedicated to the ongoing improvement of this product.

I have several alt accounts that have spend NO MONEY at all in this game and were able to complete the campaign and compete at Epic guild level.  You get PLENTY of free premium currency through login bonuses
recommended: achievements and arena quests.  You do not need to pay for the premium currency.  Still
hoursPlayed: a small purchase will speed your advancement and is a nice thank you to the developers if you like their game."

reviewText:
this game combines elements of a ccg and a lane defender. you can only use a creature to attack the creature opposite itself, which makes for more tactical potential as well as making it more balanced.


for example, if your opponent has an extreamely powerful creature on the centre lane, it wont be able to kill your creatures in the top and bottom lanes. alternatevly, if you have a flying creature in the centre lane, like a dragon, it can't be blocked by flying or ranged creatures in the other lanes


honestly, better than hearthstone.

reviewText:
Kingdoms CCG looks simple on the surface but rates high in strategy. It is simple to learn and a good deal of fun, but a good strategy will take time to develop (or you could just youtube it) and the right cards to pull off. This is where a lot of players might be iffy on the game, as getting those cards freely isn't easy. The game has a huge campaign (huge for trading card games) that has daily and hourly rewards, gives lots of nice cards, and is very challenging towards the end. By the time you finish it you should have a decent core deck and be working on the expansions. The expansion cards themselves are not more powerful than the core cards, they simply open up more and different strategies, so the power creep isn't as bad here as it is in other TCG games and new players will only be behind in terms of the options they will have immediately availble to them (a still considerable amount in my opinion)

Alot of the negative reveiws for this game stem from the P2W argument and the FB Game style energy requirement. As for the P2W argument, I simply don't understand where its coming from, and I've played a lot of actual P2W games. The latest expansions do require premium currency (diamonds) instead of gold, but premium currencty can be aquried each day through daily events. As with most F2P games, almost every card in the library (and there are a lot) can be aquried with time, patience, and a bit of grinding. If you don't like grinding (understandable) there are also free tournaments and guild play, both of which have coin rewards and the tournaments reward free tickets, which allow you access into the tournaments that give cards and diamonds for rewards. As for the cards that can't be aquired this way, they are usually event and tournament rewards. There is VIP system in place if you do wish to spend money, but none of the cards they give are more instant game winners" than many of the combinations and cards you can easily set up and aquire for free.

As for the energy issue
date: upon writing this the devs have already stated it will be removed for campaign progression. It is also not neccessary AT ALL for arena
hoursPlayed: and guild based play. The only place it will still be required is picking up the freebies and crafting items that reset daily on the campaign map and for griding old campaign nodes if you don't want to play for gold in guilds or the arena.\n\nThus far the development team has been very active
voteText: and the prospects look fairly bright for a 2yr old card game. Should anything change drastically I will update this review
helpfulPercent: but if you like TCG and have some time to kill
votesHelpful: this game is definitly worth taking a look at.\n\nEDIT: After half a year things have only gotten MUCH BETTER for this game. Those marking it down arn't really giving it a chance at all. Many of the old arena and guild systems that caused some issue are being revamped. GANZ has released 2 new
votesTotal: game changing sets (with a third on it's way shortly). Older cards have actually been rebalanced to make them either playable
votesFunny: or to reign in some of the OP nonsense that pushed many newer players away. And deck building is going to be revamped to encourage more balanced and tactically based decks
commentsCount: dealing with the no.1 complaint of some competitive decks being nothing but a mash up of the highest curved cards. Some issues remain from the time ANTIC ran this game

reviewText:
Today we have released a number of fixes and adjustments based on community feedback.

Tournaments

All Paid Tournaments (those with a Ticket Entry cost) will now award Light Ascending packs as prizes.

For our many new players, we are currently working on a new special prize pack for tournaments that will include all of the cards from our first three expansions, Eve, Rise and Tribes. When ready, we'll add this to the tournament rotation. We're also reviewing the overall tournament schedule to make it more fun for new players, including reintroducing the Pauper and Kingdoms formats. We'll have more on this in a later update.

Tribes

Tribes packs have been reduced in Gem price and are now available for Gold at a price of 20,000 per pack.

Rare Prices

The prices of rare singles in Eve, Rise and Tribes have been reduced overall.

Raise the Guard

Due to an unexpected interaction between Indestructible and self-sacrificing creatures (they don't die when Indestructible) we have removed the granting of Indestructible from Raise the Guard. We will be working to fix this interaction in an upcoming release, and at that time may reintroduce Indestructible to the card.

Note that yes, you can still achieve this using Belnir's 4 charge ability, but as this can't happen on turn 1 and takes effort to set up, we're leaving this as is.

Bug Fixes

Inverted Hourglass will no longer cause Out of Sync errors while being used in PVP.
AI Defending has been given an overhaul. It will no longer set creatures to defend improperly, and will be more likely to defend properly. Creatures with 1 Health and Armor will also no longer set themselves to Defend while Bleed is in play.
Realm Crusher will no longer count creatures with Indestructible as having been destroyed when setting its ATK/Health
Steam users can now use the Password Reset feature.

Free Gems!

Yep! This weekend (GMT) just log into Kingdoms CCG and get 20 Gems Free! Just a special thank you to all of our players for enjoying this great game!

reviewText: This game is really simple to learn, unlike some of those other MTG clones out there.  While it's true that the newest set, and the really big packs of cards do cost real money, it is entirely possible to stay relatively competitive without them.  THe game itself is fun to play, and doesn't have a real heavy ruleset to master.  The cards have good artwork, and abilities and such are explained out on each one.  THe players are friendly, and there hasn't been much of a wait for a PVP match.

reviewText: This is a great game.  I've tried a couple of online CCG before, but this is the first one that has kept me coming back for more.  The game balance is well thought out, the artwork is incredible, and some of the cards are really clever.  The individual matches are quick to play, so you can play a couple of rounds during a work break.  Also, there is a great tutorial system for anyone who is not familiar with the game mechanics.  My only complaint is that I'd love to see more campaign missions.  I'd recommend this game to anyone looking for a game with lots of enjoyment and a casual time committment.

Played it only a little to see if the people downvoting this game are right, they are.
The game is terrible in design, but artistically it's fairly good. However considering how much free play time you have it's astounding how much this game earns money. A cheap way to funnel money for not even much work. Since the game is flash-sourced, it doesn't even need fixing as content is being replaced when tehre is a problem. But lets be straight.
If you have a few minutes to lose while waiting for something, you can play this game. If you have too much money in your wallet, play this game. If you want something more interesting, I think chess would be better.

There are better free games to play, so try them out :)

However if you want to try, do so.

reviewText:
Not a bad game. Game usually ends within 7 turns. The objective is the same as any other Collectible Card Game. You can see a lot of similarities with Hearthstone.

1. Reduce your opponent's life points to zero before you do.
2. Cast Spells/Summon creatures with mana, creature have damage and hit points
3. Attack or defend
4. Add a Rune Word, Gear
4. Rinse, repeat

I'll recommend it because you ought to see what they have created. It's a good effort but the buying of expansion booster packs with cash isn't something I want to do. It will be extremely hard to make me want to come back and play repeatedly.

PROS
1. Heroes
The hero art is amazing. Unlike Hearthstone, each hero is unique. Their health points, mana gain and abilities are different. 14-16 health points, 1-3 mana gain per turn and up to 3 abilities. These abilities don't cost mana but use charges.

Something similar to the heroes from World of Warcraft The Card Game, the card game that died.

2. Campaign
The map is intriguing, You feel like you are exploring.

3. Rune Words
They work like Global Enchantments. Both players are affected by it but they expire after X number of turns. Interesting concept but there are similar ideas in Might and Magic : Duel of Champions.

4. Gear
You attach them to your hero and they have an effect. They are permanent and are pretty good to use. E.g. Longsword. Deal 1 damage to enemy hero per turn.

CONS
1. Creature Slots
Limited to 3 (1 top, 1 mid, 1 bottom)

2. Art
The map looks like a kid drew it but it is somewhat interesting. Especially when you reach the capital city. You will feel like you are exploring some thing interesting.

3. Repetition
It's the same few boring matchups. You see the same cards over and over again. E.g. Beggar/Vagrant, Traitor.

4. Crafting
Doesn't seem exciting at all. You put a core, sprinkle some essence (up to the hundreds of essence, you start with 10) and you gachapon" a potential rare card.

5. Pay-To-Win
You can get 1 booster card pack for 5000 Gold in the game but in order to get expansion packs
date: you need crystals. If they had sold expansion booster packs for Gold
hoursPlayed:
but at least someone without money could theoretically grind like crazy and get all cards.

6. Energy
You need Energy to go campaign questing. This is very silly. You're in a middle of a quest
voteText: you want to see what the developers have done.\n\nSuddenly
helpfulPercent:
you reach a point on the map where you don't have enough Energy and "5 Crystal to refill everything or 5000+5000*(no of times you used gold) to refill energy and we'll give you an additional 5 more Energy" .

Some things you should never bring over from Facebook.

7. Timers
This is like Farmville. "Wait 24 hours to click on this object
votesHelpful: so you can get your reward""

reviewText:
Fun game mechanics mired by severe balance issues. If you're a fan of card games, the campaign and sealed tournaments will provide some entertainment value.

Unfortunately the player population is low due to a combination of factors.

1. Price to complete a deck is insanely high, I almost have 2-4x of every rare in a set, opening what feels like 50-60 packs, and I still have 0 of the epic" rarity card I'm chasing. Crafting system is undeveloped and the resulting cards are based on RNG. Consecutive patches have increased the price of packs and removed gold rewards for time spent playing the game. A cautionary sign of a company trying to milk the last drops of money from a game.

2. Game balance is a joke. The ways to kill or invalidate creatures have become so mana efficient
date: that there are only three deck types left playable. Gear (enchantment) decks
hoursPlayed: or control decks that only have overpowered creatures in it (Either a 2 mana creature that comes into play and tutors a specific card in your deck

But it's balanced because you're probably gonna need to spend money to unlock it as the patch also reduces your gold gained from playing the game.\n\n3. The majority of the vocal population in the game have played for 2-3 years

reviewText:
Ok, before I start this review first to clear up two important things:

1) The game is NOT Pay to win

2) The game is NOT a Facebook game. You have energy only in campaign, not in the pvp. Progressing through campaign is optional as it gives you free cards. Besides, energy regenerates pretty fast and there is no need to spend any money here.
Don't let my number of hours played of Steam fool you, I have played this game well over 2 years, and seen some pretty drastic changes. This game had it's ups and downs, changed developers but also had a devoted community that stayed with the game the entire time.

And for a good a good reason. Kingdoms is one of the best CCG out there with very strategic combat despite it's apparent simplistic board.

Pros

Lot's of cards and lots of potential for different strategies

The combat is fun

You can buy most of the specific cards for gold in the singles market, no need for booster packs to get that specific card (gold is the in-game currency)

You can get their real money currency (gems) for free from completing daily quests, daily chests and campaign. You can use those gems to get cards faster or get some exclusive cards

Not pay to win. Although it takes a decent amount of time, you can play competitively without spending any real money. Need proof? I'm in the top 50 with no money spent EVER.


Cons

Booster packs just rose up in gold price, making it tougher for newer players to catch up to old players. A recent decision from the new devs, that's been harshly criticized from the community. We have to wait and see if they will revoke the change.

There get no rewards after from pvp after you complete all the daily quest and run out of energy in the campaign. You will have to wait tomorrow for the quests to reset. It's not too bad as it you will get to this point only after several hours.

There are some VIP cards that you can get only with real money invested in the game. Still, it's not p2w since the cards are interesting but not that often seen in the competitive scene.

There are guilds, but the guild system is not very exciting as you play against AI controlled, player constructed decks.

reviewText: If you like this kind of game, its system is solid enough and there's enough free content that it's worth signing up and trying out. That said, there are many glaring flaws. The interface is wonky. Card abilities are often explained poorly, or not at all (why don't the cards that make an enemy Weak" tell me what that means?). Each hero has several abilities
date: but the game refuses to tell you what they do until they're ready to use. In the tutorials
recommended: you can only read the details of the cards that you've been ordered to play next. There's an energy system
hoursPlayed: and I haven't played long enough to know how much it gets in the way
voteText: but there are areas in the campaign that require you to wait two real world hours to activate again and those are VERY annoying.\n\n(edit: I got a card that boosts all "Light Alliance" creatures
helpfulPercent: but I didn't seem to have any L.A. creatures... turns out that L.A. refers to three "good guy" factions
votesHelpful: which they could have just easily written out on the card. Worst keyword system ever!)"

reviewText: While the game can be admittedly pricey. I'd go so far as to say is Kingdoms is the best online only CCG I've ever played. I've played the other ones on here, Solforge, Infinity Wars, Might And Magic, Bloodrealm Battlegrounds. And after awhile it just feels like your just banging cards together and playing a slightly more advanced variation of war. Kingdoms has so much more variety with what you could do with your decks. Aggro, control, mid-range, burn, tons of combo decks that play totally differently. The Heroes" you can choose to play your deck with are really diverse
date: each one feels really different and has a huge effect on the game. The creatures
recommended: gears and spells you can play can do so much interesting stuff.\n\nMore so than any other online CCG
hoursPlayed: I'd say that this game is closer to the complexity and diversity of Magic: The Gathering. And if you've played M:TG
voteText: you'll be able to pick this up in like 5 minutes. It's got the same basic concept of mana
votesHelpful:
kill your opponent by attacking with guys and using spells. And It's nice that mana isn't some randomly inserted cards in your deck that you might not draw and have to lose a game for kind of a stupid reason. You just always get 2 mana a turn unless something is changing that.

There's a decent amount of different formats and different ways you can play. A format for players with more stuff that has almost no restrictions on what you can run. A format with limitations on how many of the rares cards you can use that's more quickly accessible to new players. You can play against AI if you're not ready to play real players and still earn the in game currency. There's a guild system that really helps you to earn gold and get a better idea about deck building with tiers that range from people just starting to top level competitive stuff. And there's a really active chat right on the side of the game and people are generally pretty chill and willing to help with questions and the best stuff to do when you're getting started.

This is the CCG I've stuck with for 2 and a half years (on a different site
votesTotal: not Steam. Hence the not having a lot of time on the game here) and still actively play. No other online CCG ever kept my interest like that."

reviewText:
My experiences with this game have been both positive and negative.
Kingdoms CCG has a lot of issues. Mainly because it tried to combine and add loads of content, back with the old developers, without thinking it trough.
However, when i compare this CCG to Hearthstone i see more potential and strategic deckbuilding here and that's why i'd recommend this game to all CCG fans. If you manage to overcome the confusing layout and navigation you'd discover the amazing depth this game has to offer.

Take it slow and don't fret because you can't get all the cards right away ;P

Edit: While i still agree with my previous statement that this game has potential, the current developers have failed in improving the game in the right ways, which is why i'm changing my review.
Even with the latest update: New Player improvement" It's impossible for new players to get a decent deck
date: that'll pair up with others in arena
recommended: trough campaign rewards.\n\nThe game should quickly let people get "good" at the game
hoursPlayed: but then make it a grind to become masters."
voteText: February 20, 2015
